awd_titl_txt: Forum on Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders
awd_abstract_narration:
The human nervous system is remarkably complex, and nervous system disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease and depression pose a substantial public health and economic challenge, affecting approximately half of Americans at some point in life. Understanding how the nervous system develops, functions, and ages—in both health and disease—is critical for developing safe and effective treatments. Many federal agencies are involved in this endeavor—including the National Science Foundation, National Institutes of Health, Department of Veterans Affairs, Food and Drug Administration, and Department of Defense—as well as academic researchers, private sector companies, disease-focused organizations, and philanthropic foundations. To tackle fundamental questions about the brain, it is also becoming increasingly important to extend beyond traditional neuroscience and integrate expertise across a broad range of fields, including social and behavioral sciences, mathematics, statistics, materials science, physics, computer science, and engineering. Recognizing the need for crosscutting efforts, in 2006 the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine established the Forum on Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders to convene the wide range of leaders and stakeholders in this domain. Through its meetings, workshops, and other activities, the Forum tackles emerging issues and key challenges related to scientific needs and opportunities, priority setting, and policies related to fundamental neuroscience research; the development, regulation, and use of treatments; and related ethical, legal, and social implications. With this award, NSF continues to join other participating federal agencies and organizations in supporting this neutral venue for exchanging information, differing perspectives, and opportunities for collective action. 

The Neuroscience Forum brings together leaders from government, industry, academia, disease advocacy organizations, and other interested stakeholders. Neuroscience Forum members meets two or three times per year and the Forum also sponsors two or three public workshops per year, publishes workshop proceedings, and commissions papers as additional mechanisms for engaging its membership, other experts and stakeholders, and the public. To ensure that the Neuroscience Forum serves as a venue for on-going and timely discussions, topics are selected by the members to address emerging needs and advances in the field. In recent years, the Neuroscience Forum has addressed topics such as disseminating tools and technologies that are being developed through the BRAIN Initiative, legal implications of emerging neurotechnologies, scientific opportunities afforded by new transgenic nonhuman primate models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine's Forum on Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders (the "Neuroscience Forum") was established in 2006 to bring together leaders from government, academia, industry, and the non-profit sector to examine significant and sometimes contentious issues concerning scientific opportunities, priority setting, and policies related to research on neuroscience and brain disorders; the development, regulation, and use of interventions for the nervous system; and related ethical, legal, and social implications.

The Neuroscience Forum provides a communal, neutral venue to foster dialogue across sectors and institutions. Representatives from government, academia, industry, non-profit associations, philanthropic foundations, and other interested parties serve as members of the Neuroscience Forum. Members meet two or three times per year to exchange information, ideas, and differing perspectives regarding emerging scientific and policy issues related to research in the neurosciences. The three Forum membership meetings held during this award period (June 14, 2023; March 13, 2023; October 25, 2022) addressed a variety of topics relating to the Forum's priorities, including: key issues and open question in decentralized trials in neuroscience; the UK Life Sciences 10-year strategy and implications to accelerating therapeutic development for dementia and mental health disorders; state of the science updates on gene-targeted therapies, neuromodulation, and nonhuman brain research; current issues related to neural tubal defects research and efforts to spur reinvestment; global mental health; emerging areas in artificial intelligence and neuroscience; research and development for rare neurological disorders; and planning for future Neuroscience Forum activities.

In addition to membership meetings, every year the Neuroscience Forum hosts public workshops on topics selected by the membership. Following each workshop, a proceedings is published by the National Academies Press and made available as a free downloadable PDF at http://www.nap.edu.

The Neuroscience Forum regularly tackles topics that integrate fundamental neuroscience research with preclinical and clinical research to help advance development of therapies for nervous system disorders, which are common, major causes of premature mortality, and, in aggregate, the largest cause of disability worldwide. During the 2022-2023 award period, the Neuroscience Forum hosted six public workshops.

  • Toward a Common Research Agenda in Infection-Associated Chronic Illnesses: A Workshop to Examine a Common, Overlapping Clinical and Biological Factors (June 29-30, 2023)
  • Addressing Health Disparities in Central Nervous System Disorders: Driving Transformative Change (April 25, 2023)
  • Addressing Health Disparities in Central Nervous System Disorders: Access to Care (April 18, 2023)
  • Addressing Health Disparities in Central Nervous System Disorders: Social and Structural Risks (April 13, 2023)
  • Multimodal Biomarkers for Central Nervous System Disorders: Development, Integration, and Clinical Utility (March 13-14, 2023)
  • Exploring Sleep Disturbance in Central Nervous System Disorders (November 2-3, 2022)

During the current award period, the Forum also published and disseminated the following three publications based on workshops:

  • Multimodal Biomarkers for Central Nervous System Disorders: Development, Validation, and Clinical Integration: Proceedings of a Workshop (2023)
  • Exploring Sleep Disturbance in Central Nervous System Disorders: Proceedings of a Workshop (2023)
  • Exploring Psychedelics and Entactogens as Treatments for Psychiatric Disorders: Proceedings of a Workshop (2022)

These publications were disseminated through a variety of mechanisms:

  • Members of the Forum and workshop speakers distribute them to their professional networks.
  • The Forum's public listserv reaches approximately 4,000 interested individuals.
  • The National Academies' Health and Medicine Division distributes information about our work via email listservs to readers interested in substance use and mental health (14,000+ subscribers) and new reports (12,000+ subscribers), Twitter (68,000+ followers), Facebook (12,500+ page followers), and LinkedIn (6,500+ followers).

To increase the accessibility of the Neuroscience Forum's work, a 5-minute post-workshop recap video comprised of interviews with the planning committee co-chairs and select clips from speakers was released in conjunction with the workshop proceedings on multimodal biomarkers.

Overall, the Neuroscience Forum's activities aim to inspire new ideas and shape the field, foster relationships and collaboration, develop an improved understanding of each other's perspectives and priorities, and influence policies and programs. Discussions or workshops may lead to proposals for specific studies by units of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine resulting in institutional reports. Such studies, if undertaken, will be conducted independently from the Neuroscience Forum and in accordance with all institutional policies and procedures governing such study activities.
